Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Solomon... Solomon, turning back to his wife with a broad smile waving her forward:

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Come, Anne. Jump.

Speaker: alonzo margaret
Dialogue: Jump. You can make it. I've done it. You can make it.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I will not ruin my dress. Catch me!  Solomon moves close, holds out his arms. Yet, there's still just a bit of mischievousness in his eyes. Anne gives her husband a lightly stern look to which Solomon replies.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I will catch you, Anne.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: You will.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Mr. Parker.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Mr. Northup. Mrs. Northup.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: We are in need of a fresh carry all for the Mrs's travels.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: A year's passed? Off to Sandy Hill?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I am. Using a long pole, Mr. Parker fetches down a CARRY ALL from an upper shelf.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Something to suit your style, but sturdy enough for the forty miles round trip. Handing the Bag to Anne, she is immediately taken by it.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: It's beautiful.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: We will take it. Children, come see what your father has just purchased for me. As the children run over - chattering excitedly about the new gift - they RUN PAST JASPER who has quietly entered the store. At the checkout counter sits a portrait of WILLIAM HENRY HARRISON, the edges draped in black crepe. Before the book sits a LEDGER. Mr. Parker asks of Solomon:

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: If you would sign our condolence book. My hope is to find a way to forward it to the Widow Harrison. Sad days for the nation.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Yes, certainly. Poor Mrs. Harris and her children. I hope brighter times ahead.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: A moment, sir, and you will be assisted.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: If we could discuss the price...

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Forgive me, Mrs. Northup. A customer waits. Welcome, sir. To Jasper, with good nature:

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Shop well, but mind your wallet.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Ignore the gentleman's nonsense. Now, may I interest you in a new cravat? Pure silk by way of the-- Before Parker can finish, the door opens. It's Jasper's Master, FITZGERALD. He's stern, clearly displeased.

Speaker: fitzgerald
Dialogue: Jasper!

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: No intrusion. Fitzgerald looks to Solomon. It is a cold glare as though he wasn't speaking to, and has no interest in a response from a black man. Looking back to Parker:

Speaker: fitzgerald
Dialogue: Good day, sir.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: "Thus has passed away from earth our late President." Solomon starts from the top of the article.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Will you read it again?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Not just now, darling. Anne enters the dining room and places a large chicken at the center of the table. As she takes a seat, all heads are bowed.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: For food that stays our hunger, For rest that brings us ease, For homes where memories linger, We give our thanks for these.

Speaker: all
Dialogue: Amen.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Margaret, that was wonderful.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Thank you, Papa.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Alonzo, do you have something to say?

Speaker: alonzo
Dialogue: Yes, I helped Momma make this.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Yes, and you were such a good help. Especially making the gravy.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Papa, I would very much like to learn how to play the violin. Could you teach me?

Speaker: alonzo
Dialogue: Me too!

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Yes, but I asked Papa first.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Both of you, calm down. We will have our first lesson after this wonderful dinner. And on that note, let's start eating.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Travel safely.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Stay safely. Anne and the children loaded up, the Driver chides the horse and the carriage heads off. Solomon waves a hearty good bye to his wife and children.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Sir.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: He was indeed.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Mr. Moon is being overly gracious.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Taking into consideration his graciousness and your modesty, may we trouble you for a moment of your time to converse, sir?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: A circus?

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: That is our usual employee. The company currently in the city of Washington.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Circus too constricting a word to describe the talented and merry band with which we travel. It is a spectacle unlike most have ever witnessed. Creatures from the darkest Africa as yet unseen by civilized man. Acrobats from the Orient able to contort themselves in the most confounding manners.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: And I myself in aide of Mr. Brown; an internationally renowned practitioner in the art of prestidigitation.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: We are on our way thither to rejoin the company having left for a short time to make a small profit from our own exhibitions.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: The reason for our inquiry with Mr. Moon...

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Yes. We had just a devil of a time in procuring music for our

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Thank you sir...

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: If we could persuade you to accompany us as far as New York... We would give you one dollar for each day's service and three dollars for every night played at our performances. In addition we would provide sufficient pay for the expenses of your return from New York here to Saratoga.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: You understand this is all very sudden.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: Consider it an opportunity to see

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: It's intriguing...

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: If there is any way in which you would give consideration to the offer... Solomon gives the whole deal one last consideration.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: The payment offered is enticement enough, as is my desire to visit the metropolis.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: We are delighted, sir. So delighted. Though we would add that our travel plans--

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: We would like to depart with haste.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: As luck would have it, my wife and children are traveling. I will write her of our plans.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Excellent! I would beg you collect yourself, then we may proceed.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: No letter to post?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: No need. My return will coincide with my family's.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: We're off then.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: Not an additional tip from a one of them. They expect to be entertained for nothing.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: And not satisfied a bit despite giving them more than what they paid for.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: It's the national mood. There's too much grief to make room for frivolity.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: My sincerest apologies, Solomon. You were promised opportunity, and you were given none.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: The opportunity is with the circus. A two man show poorly promoted, what were we to expect? But the circus bills itself.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I have told you of the circus with which we are connected. Creatures from the darkest of Africa. Acrobats from the Orient who--

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: You have described it, yes.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Yes. We need to return immediately to Washington. Solomon...I believe us familiar enough now, but forgive me if I am bold...would you consider making the trip with us? Solomon gives a bit of a laugh at the idea.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: Entertaining at pubs and inns has it's place, but a man of your skills deserves better.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Hear, hear.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: And more importantly you would build your own name and following. The circus tends to attract those with the highest of reputations. An introduction here and there could amount to a lifetime of reward. Now would be the time. With your family away, an opportunity presents itself.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Said as fellow artists as well as businessmen. Well worth the effort at least.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: You present a flattering representation. As my family will be traveling back shortly, perhaps I might commit only to one trial engagement.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: Oh, very good, sir. Very good. I cannot recall being so excited.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: There is a practical concern. If you are to continue on with us you should obtain your free papers.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Not necessary.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Here in New York, no. But we will be entering slave states and as a matter of precaution... It's to all our benefit we should not have to come to account for your well being.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: Six shillings worth of effort could well save much trouble later.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: We'll go to the Customs House in the morning, then travel on. Good business all around.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Forty-three dollars. All to you.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: That...it's far more than my wages amount to.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Consider the remainder an advance from the circus. I cannot tell you...I honestly wish you had seen the expression of our director when I described your abilities. He was fairly overcome with excitement.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: You should have invited him to sup with us.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I did. I did, but so many preparations before the company is to depart.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Tomorrow we shall prepare for our Washington debut. But tonight, our thoughts are with the great man

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: Cheers.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Another. Our departed President deserves all the salutation we can imbibe. Hamilton and Brown drink again, and Solomon does as well.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: That's all right Solomon. No shame in it. No shame at all.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: I'm afraid that Brown and I haven't brought you much luck. But rough waters bring smooth sailing. Eventually they do.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: ....So...so sorry...

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: Shhh. We won't hear it. We won't.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Let him sleep.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: Hmm. A good night's sleep. And tomorrow...tomorrow you will feel as well and refreshed as though the earth were new again. Hamilton lingers a bit too long and a bit too close to Solomon for Brown's taste. With more than a bit of

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Hamilton! Nothing more we can do for him.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: Such is the pity. Displaying an odd sort of disappointment, Hamilton slinks away from the bed. He crosses to, and BLOWS OUT A CANDLE. The room goes dark with a blackness more than night. Brown and Hamilton exit. Solomon lays in the dark and moans. His sounds becoming MORE AND MORE

Speaker: burch
Dialogue: Well, my boy, how yah feel now? Solomon rises up as best he can. With all the resolve he can put together he states what he considers to be fact:

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I am Solomon Northup. I am a free man; a resident of Saratoga, New York. The residence also of my wife and children who are equally free. I have papers. You have no right whatsoever to detain me--

Speaker: burch
Dialogue: Yah not any--

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: And I promise you - I promise - upon my liberation I will have satisfaction for this wrong.

Speaker: burch
Dialogue: Resolve this. Produce your papers.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: ...I...I insist... Burch regrets hearing this. Not from sympathy, but rather because he's nearly too tired to go back to beating Solomon. Yet, as if returning to work, Burch returns to pummeling Solomon. Burch punctuates the blows

Speaker: burch
Dialogue: Yah a slave. Yah a Georgia slave! Burch continues to strike, and strike... This time until the paddle SNAPS IN HALF. Burch then GRABS THE WHIP. Hardly missing a stroke, he whips Solomon relentlessly, the flails cutting into Solomon's back. Again, Burch's arm tires before Solomon "breaks."

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: ...No... Burch goes back to whipping and whipping, and whipping...

Speaker: radburn
Dialogue: I seen a good many of the black kind just where yah're. Sick. Make me sick. Often times the situation was resolved, and I think; what was all the beatin' and abuse for? Things end as they should, and the violence was for naught. So why cause trouble when they ain't no cause for it? Be of a cooperative nature, and things don't need be particularly unpleasant.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Help me! Someone help me! If anyone at all hears him, they do not respond. Solomon continues his plaintive cry for assistance.

Speaker: radburn
Dialogue: Go on. Warsh up. The men, soaking in humility as well as water, begin to scrub with A SINGLE BAR OF HARSH SOAP passed among them.

Speaker: randall
Dialogue: Do you know when my Mama will come?

Speaker: radburn
Dialogue: Hush him up! Seeing Solomon has no answer for him, Randall begins to cry.

Speaker: randall
Dialogue: Mama ..! Mama! Is she going to come? Doing all he can to spare the child from a certain

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Quiet, please. Randall is becoming nearly inconsolable.

Speaker: randall
Dialogue: Mama!

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Your mother will come, I swear she will, but you must be silent. Please. Be silent! On the seeming strength of Solomon's promise, Randall goes silent. Solomon looks to Radburn, who just throws water on the soapy men.

Speaker: radburn
Dialogue: That old thing of yours is just rags and tatters. Need something proper to wear. Solomon doesn't move for the clothing.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: ...Thank you...

Speaker: radburn
Dialogue: Yah keep bein' proper, yah'll see how things work out. Radburn starts to take the old shirt.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: No! It was from my wife.

Speaker: radburn
Dialogue: Rags and tatters. Rags and tatters. Taking the shirt, the "rags and tatters" as he calls them, Radburn exits, locking the door behind him. Solomon sits with the plate of food before him. He pushes the plate away rather than eat.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: This can't stand. It is a crime. I believe now someone lay in wait for me. My drink was altered... We are free men. They have...they have no right to hold us. Solomon waits for a response from the others. They give none.

Speaker: clemens
Dialogue: Who in your estimation is that sympathetic ear?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: The two men I journeyed with. I'm certain they're making inquires at this very moment.

Speaker: clemens
Dialogue: I would be just as certain they are counting the money paid for delivering you to this place.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: They were not kidnappers. They were artists. Fellow performers.

Speaker: clemens
Dialogue: You know that? You know for certain who they were?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: clemens
Dialogue: I don't say that to give you empty agitation, John...

Speaker: john
Dialogue: For y'all. For y'all they ain't nothin' but that! But John was'n kidnapped. John bein' hold as debt, tha's all. Massa pay his debt, and John be redeemed--

Speaker: clemens
Dialogue: Boy, our masters will not come for us. John is nearly beside himself with panic.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Now John's...John's sorry for y'all, but tha's how it be. Where y'all goin', yah goin' witout John. Massa take care of me. Massa take care.

Speaker: randall
Dialogue: Mama! All three men turn and look. At the moment Randall doesn't call out emptily. At the door to the yard is Burch along with two women. One in her late twenties; ELIZA. She is "arrayed in silk, with rings upon her fingers, and golden ornaments suspended from her ears." Though a slave, Eliza was a mistress and has - to this point - lived well. This is reflected in her airs and her speech. The other is a little girl, light in skin color, of about seven or eight. This is EMILY, Randall's half sister. As she enters the yard Eliza squeals with high delight, then breaks into tears of both sorrow and joy. Clearly this is mother and child being reunited.

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: My darling. My sweet, sweet baby.

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: When I say I had my master's favor, you understand. Above even his own wife, I had it. Do you know that he built a house for me? Built it on the sole condition that I reside there with him. The added promise in time I would be emancipated. And for nine years he blessed me with every comfort and luxury in life. Displaying the finery she still wears:

Speaker: burch
Dialogue: Come on. Get yer blankets. Get up. Sensing that things will not end well:

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: No, please don't...

Speaker: burch
Dialogue: I don't want to hear yer talk. Get in the yard.

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: Please...

Speaker: radburn
Dialogue: Ain't no need for all that. Putting hand to Randall's head.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: John's massa gunna pay his debt. John's massa gunna come for him.

Speaker: burch
Dialogue: Not a word out of none a yah. Not a word. Burch and Radburn begin driving the shackled slaves from the yard.

Speaker: mulatto woman
Dialogue: Cheer up and don't be so cast down.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Clemens...! Clemens Ray! We are in the port of New Orleans, one of the busiest in the young nation. On the dock itself there is a bustle of activity as goods are loaded and unloaded from a various ships. It's a bit of controlled chaos as a VARIETY OF LANGUAGES are spoken and shouted while slaves are shuttled from the Orleans to a holding pen. Solomon, and all the slaves are overwhelmed by all that is happening around them. Two men - among many - are awaiting the arrival of the Orleans. They are JONUS RAY - Clemens Ray's master - and DAVIS who is the solicitor of Mr. Ray. They both look like they mean business. The moment the gangplank is laid, Ray yells for Clemens. Clemens, seeing his master, is nearly crazy with delight. He is, uncharacteristically beside himself. Ironically, his master now represents "freedom."

Speaker: clemens
Dialogue: ...My master... Master Ray, sir! Master Ray! Clemens pulls on his chain. As he does so, Several other slaves collapse in his effort to reach his master, like dominos.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Who is in charge of this vessel?

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: I am the Captain.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I am Mr. Jonus Ray. My solicitor has documentation verifying that the Negro named Clemens Ray is my property. As he reads PAPERS handed to him by Davis:

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: I know nothing of--

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You are ordered by court to return that property immediately, or face charges of thievery.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: My duty is to transport goods. I am not responsible for their origin.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Remove these contraptions! To his mate:

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Free him! Biddee does as ordered. Once free, Clemens hugs and sobs over his master as would a lost and then found child.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: It's all well, now, Clemens. You will return home with me.  Consider this notice and warning.

Speaker: freeman
Dialogue: Oren. John. Lethe. Eliza. Randall. Emily. Platt... Platt! Solomon does not respond. Freeman looks around. He spots Solomon.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Burch. Freeman steps to Solomon. He gives him a looking over.

Speaker: freeman
Dialogue: Stand up. Solomon does as told.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: My name is not Platt. My name is-- Freeman strikes Solomon hard across the face.

Speaker: freeman
Dialogue: Your name is Platt, and I will teach you your name so that you don't forget.  Shackle my niggers. Get them to my cart.

Speaker: freeman
Dialogue: Tallest to smallest, understand? Are you taller than her? Then you'd go before her. Do it. Move.  Keep your heads up. A sense of direction; that's how you look smart. None of those saucer eyes. Rid yourself of that smile. Look like a goddamn grinnin' monkey. Put the least thought in your head. C'mon, now. Think of somethin'. Weary of Cape's playing, Solomon moves to Cape. He asks:

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Can you play a reel?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: If I may...? Cape looks to Freeman:

Speaker: freeman
Dialogue: He sick of your caterwaulin'. Let him play, boy. Let's see what he can do. Cape reluctantly hands the fiddle over to Solomon. Solomon tunes it a bit, then begins to play. His fingers stiff at first, he takes a moment to warm up. But as he warms up he is, despite the circumstances, masterful.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: What is the price for the ones Platt and Eliza?

Speaker: freeman
Dialogue: A thousand for Platt; he is a nigger of talent. Seven hundred for Eliza. My fairest price.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: You will accept a note?

Speaker: freeman
Dialogue: As always, from you, Mr. Ford. Eliza is beside herself as it seems she is about to be separated from her family. She begs of Ford:

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: Please, sir... Please don't divide my family. Don't take me unless you take my children as well.

Speaker: freeman
Dialogue: Eliza, quiet!

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: You will have the most faithful slave in me, sir. The most faithful slave that has ever lived, but I beg that you do not separate us. A BUYER interrupts the skirmish and approaches Freeman and delivers coolly, eyeing Randall-

Speaker: buyer
Dialogue: Your price for the child?

Speaker: freeman
Dialogue: You see how fit the boy is. Like ripe fruit. He will grow into a fine beast. Randall is made to run, and jump by FREEMAN - exhibiting his activity and his condition.

Speaker: buyer
Dialogue: Done. He reaches into his waistcoat and retrieves his wallet, counting out six hundred dollars, placing them into the already extended hand of Freeman. Ford sees the distress and panic in Eliza; it visibly touches him. He now tries to buy EMILY to console her.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: How much for the little girl? You have no need for her. One so young will bring you no profit.

Speaker: freeman
Dialogue: I will not sell the girl. There's heaps 'n piles of money to be made off her. She is a beauty. One of the regular bloods. None of your thick-lipped, bullet headed, cotton picking niggers.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Her child, man. For God's sake, are you not sentimental in the least?

Speaker: freeman
Dialogue: My sentimentality stretches the length of a coin. Do you want the lot, Mr. Ford, or do you pass on them all?

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: I will take the ones Platt and Eliza. Eliza grips her children tight.

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: I will not go without my children. You will not take them from me.

Speaker: freeman
Dialogue: Take her out of here. Cape DROPS HIS FIDDLE, begins to pull Eliza away toward the door of the room, but her screaming and pleading do not abate. IT IS CLEARLY UNSETTLING TO THE OTHER BUYERS.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Mama... Mama!

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Don't cry, Mama. I will be a good girl. Don't cry. I will keep my head up and I will look smart. I will always look smart.

Speaker: freeman
Dialogue: Make merry, all of you! Goddamn it, Cape! Keep her quiet or it's your damned hide I will take it out of! Cape pulls a rag, stuffs it in Eliza's mouth. Clamping both hands over her mouth, he hauls Eliza from the room by the head. IT IS AN UGLY, UGLY SCENE.

Speaker: chapin
Dialogue: Sam, call to the Mistress.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Mistress! Mistress, they arrivn'. MISTRESS FORD EXITS the house - along with her attending slave, RACHEL, who is a cook AS WELL AS SAM'S WIFE - and travels to her husband, kisses him, then laughingly

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Make me something to eat, dear. The day has taken it from me.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Mr. Chapin--

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Separated from her children.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: It couldn't be helped.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Mr. Chapin, tomorrow you will take these two up to the mill and start them workin'. For now make them

Speaker: chapin
Dialogue: Yes, sir.  C'mon, now. C'mon. Don't dawdle.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: "But as touching the resurrection of the dead, have ye not read that which was spoken unto you by God, saying, I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob. God is not the God of the dead, but of the living. And when the multitude heard this, they were astonished at his doctrine. Then one of them, which was a lawyer, asked him a question, tempting him, and saying, Master, which is the great commandment in the law? Jesus said unto him, Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind. This is the first and great commandment. And the second is like unto it, thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself. On these two commandments hang all the law and the prophets." Despite the lightness with which Ford speaks and the hope in his words, ELIZA SITS OFF TO THE SIDE - SELF-SECLUDED

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: But he that is greatest among you, let him be as the younger; and he that is chief, as he that doth serve. For whether is greater, he that sitteth at meat, or he that serveth? Is not he that sitteth at meat? But I am among you as he that serveth. A white customer - WINSLOW - irate at the sight and sound of slaves reading Scripture, crosses over. He grabs the Bible.

Speaker: winslow
Dialogue: From where did you thieve this?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Suh, the book is my property. The White Customer has no interest in Sam's answer. With flailing hands he STARTS BEATING ON SAM. Solomon tries to stop him. That only makes the situation worse, Solomon now the target of the man's ire.

Speaker: winslow
Dialogue: Take your hands from me! Ford comes running over.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: What is the commotion?

Speaker: winslow
Dialogue: Your niggers are either brazen or rebellious. This one was readin' Scripture, and this one claims it to be his.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: It is. A gift from his Mistress.

Speaker: winslow
Dialogue: You condone this?

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: I encourage it. As a Christian I can do no less.

Speaker: winslow
Dialogue: You can do no worse, Ford. A slave that reads is dangerous. Winslow moves off. He yells back at Ford:

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Pay him no mind. The word of God applies to all. In that you may take comfort.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: The creek is plenty deep enough to sail, even with a boat full of load. The distance from the WORK AREA to the point on the latter bayou is several miles by water fewer than land. It occurs to me that the expense of the transportation would be materially

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: "Materially diminished?"

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: If we use the waterway.

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: It's a scheme. Plenty of engineers have schemed similarly. The passes are too tight.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I reckon them at more than twelve feet at their most narrow. Wide enough for a tub to traverse. A team of niggers can clear it out.

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: And you know what of transport and terra formin'?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I labored repairing the Champlain canal, on the section over which William Van Nortwick was superintendent. With my earnings I hired several efficient hands to assist me, and I entered into contracts for the transportation of large rafts of timber from Lake Champlain to Troy.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: My great thanks, Master Ford.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: My thanks to you, and it is the least of it. My hope is that it brings us both much joy over the years. Following the statement, Solomon's not sure how to react. He remains grateful, but the thought of "over the years" is just a reminder of the altered state in which he now finds himself.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Eliza. Eliza, stop! Solomon goes to her, grabs Eliza. She does not stop. As if to force the misery from her, Solomon SHAKES ELIZA

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: It's all I have to keeps my loss present.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: You let yourself be overcome by sorrow. You will drown in it.

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: Have you stopped crying for your children? You make no sounds, but will you ever let them go in your heart?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: ...They are as my flesh...

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: Then who is distressed? Do I upset the Mistress and the Master? Do you care less for my loss than their well being?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Master Ford is a decent man.

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: He is a slaver.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Under the circumstances--

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: Under the circumstances he is a slaver! Christian only in his proclamations. Separated me from my precious babies for lack of a few dollars. But you truckle at

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: You luxuriate in his favor.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I survive. I will not fall into despair. Woeful and crushed; melancholy is the yolk I see most. I will offer up my talents to Master Ford. I will keep myself hearty until freedom is opportune.

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: Ford is your opportunity. Do you think he does not know that you are more than you suggest? But he does nothing for you. Nothing. You are no better than prized livestock. Call for him. Call, tell him of your previous circumstances and see what it earns you...Solomon. Eliza uses Solomon's name quite pointedly as if to underscore his true self. Solomon get her meaning. Yet he says nothing. Again, pointedly:

Speaker: eliza
Dialogue: I accuse you of nothing. I cannot accuse. I too have done so many, many dishonorable things to survive. And for all of them I have ended up here... No better than if I had stood up for myself. Father, Lord and Savior forgive me... Forgive me. Oh, Solomon, let me weep for my children.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: And Jesus called a little child unto him, and set him in the midst of them, And said, Verily I say unto you, Except ye be converted, and become as little children, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven. The phrase seems to trigger Eliza's tears. She begins to sob uncontrollably. Mrs. Ford turns to Rachel in a hushed whisper-

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: But whoso shall offend one of these little ones which believe in me, it were better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck, and that he were drowned in the depth of the sea. Woe unto

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: Raise yer shirt. Solomon does as instructed. Tibeats looks at Solomon's back, at the scars from lashings he bears.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: He's a good carpenter and quick- witted.

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: I am familiar with his cleverness.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: You won't find a nigger more humble.

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: Ain't found a nigger yet I cain't humble. Tibeats heads off. Solomon, highly curious over the preceding.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Sir, have I done something wrong?

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Not your concern, Platt. I say with much...shame I have compiled debts. I have long preached austerity, but find myself hypocritical in that regard. You'll be in the ownership of Mr. Tibeats. You are his now. Serve him as you'd serve me.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Sir.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: And your faithfulness will not be forgotten.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Pride and want have been my sin. Loss of you is but one of my punishments.

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: Make them boards flush.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: They are, sir.

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: They is no such thing. Solomon runs his hands over the boards.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: As smooth to the touch as a yearling's coat.

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: Callin' me a liar, boy?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Only a matter of perspective, sir. From where you stand you may see differently. But the hands are not mistaken. I ask only that you employ all your senses before rendering judgement. What's Tibeats to do when faced with fact? All he can do is spew invectives.

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: You are a brute. You are a dog, and no better for followin' instruction.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I'll do as ordered, sir.

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: Then you'll be up at daybreak. You will procure a keg of nails from Chapin and commence puttin' on clapboards. Tibeats wheels away. Solomon goes back to his work. After a few moments Solomon notices a bit of commotion in the drive of the great house. It involves an inconsolable Eliza who is being herded by Sam onto a cart DRIVEN BY A WHITE MAN. Mistress Ford and Rachel watch. Solomon can only watch as the last connection to his days as a free man is driven away to a location unknown.

Speaker: chapin
Dialogue: If Tibeats prefers a different size, I will endeavor to furnish them, but you may use those until further directed.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: I thought I told yah ta commence ta puttin' on clapboards this morn'.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Yes, master. I am about it. I have begun on the other side of the house. Tibeats walks around to look over Solomon's work. He is picayune, as if purposefully looking for fault.

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: Didn't I tell yah last night to get a keg of nails of Chapin?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: And so I did; and Chapin said he would get another size for you, if you wanted them when he came back from the field. Tibeats walks to the keg and kicks it. Moving toward Solomon "with a great passion:"

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: Goddamn yah! I thought yah knowed somethin'! Solomon, perhaps inspired by his moment with Eliza, is in no mood for Tibeats.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I did as instructed. If there's something wrong, then its wrong with your instructions.

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: Yah black bastard! Yah goddman black bastard! In an inconsolable rage, Tibeats runs off to the piazza to fetch a whip. Solomon looks around. He is alone other than Rachel and Mistress Ford who, shocked by that which she witnesses, runs out to the field to fetch Chapin. Solomon's instinct is to run, but he stands his ground as Tibeats marches back whip in hand.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I will not. With "concentrated vengeance," Tibeats springs for Solomon, seizing him by the throat with one hand and

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: Yew will not live ta see another day, nigger! This is yer last, I swear it! Solomon ignores the threats, continues to beat Tibeats. Blow after blow falling fast and heavy on Tibeats's wriggling form. The stiff stock of the whip wraps around Tibeats's cringing body until Solomon's arm aches. Tibeats's cries of vengeance turn to yelps for help and then pleas for mercy:

Speaker: chapin
Dialogue: What is the matter? Tibeats struggles up and tries to present an air of dignity and control while he keeps a demonic eye on

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Master Tibeats wants to whip me for using the nails you gave me.

Speaker: chapin
Dialogue: What's the matter with the nails? With a mix of shame, anger and embarrassment, Tibeats says, as if being exposed-

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: They're...they're too large.

Speaker: chapin
Dialogue: I am overseer here. I told Platt to use them, and

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: This ain't done by half. I will have flesh, and I will have all of it. Tibeats moves off toward, and then INTO THE HOUSE. Chapin follows. A long moment, Solomon stands alone. He looks around, not sure what to do; to stay or to flee. Anxiety mounts on his features. A moment more, and Tibeats EXITS the house. He saddles his horse and rides off to beat the devil. Or, worse, to fetch him. Chapin comes running back out of the house. He is visibly excited, and when he speaks he is quite earnest. Though he tries to project reasoned emotions he gives off an air of impending trouble.

Speaker: chapin
Dialogue: Do not stir. Do not attempt to leave the plantation on any account whatever. But if you run there is no protecting you.

Speaker: chapin
Dialogue: If you run, Platt, there is no protecting you. Rachel...! Chapin runs off to join Rachel. The two converse at a distance from Solomon, then they head off for the log kitchen. Solomon is now very much alone, and he waits for what is to come. AND WE WAIT WITH HIM. And we wait, and we continue to wait... Moment by moment, the dread of the unexpected mounts. Solomon's eyes begin to well. He has beaten a white man, and he knows that death awaits him.

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: Tha's the one. Tha's him. Dismounting, they move with menace that is tinged with perverse pleasure and wordless malevolence. Solomon tries to fight back, but he is strong armed and tied by TIBEATS - his wrists, and then ankles bound in the same manner. In the meantime the other two have slipped a cord within Solomon's elbows, running it across his back and tying it firmly. Solomon is then dragged toward a peach tree. A lynching is in store. The naked horror of it intensely palpable. Solomon looks toward the piazza, but Chapin is now gone. Tears of fear flow down Solomon's cheeks. He is on the verge of panic; a man heading toward his own execution, he begins to struggle and fight. A rope goes around Solomon's neck, then is tossed over the branch of the tree. The trio begin to hoist Solomon. He gasps and gags as spittle flies from his mouth and the life is choked from him. With suddenness, Chapin comes from the house brandishing a pistol in each hand - Colt Paterson .36 caliber "Holster" pistols with 9" barrels. Chapin moves with determination toward the lynch mob. He is sharp and matter of fact. With the guns in hand, he really doesn't need to be much more demonstrative.

Speaker: chapin
Dialogue: Gentlemen... Whoever moves that nigger another foot from where he stands is a dead man. I am overseer of this plantation seven years, and in the absence of William Ford, my duty is to protect his interests. Ford holds a mortgage on Platt of four hundred dollars. If you hang him, he loses his debt. Until that is canceled you have no claim to his life. Directing his attention to Ramsay and Cook:

Speaker: tibeats
Dialogue: Yah got no cause. Platt is mine, and mine ta do with as I please. Yah touch my property, I will 'ave yah strung up as well. Tibeats mounts up and departs. There is a surreal moment as Chapin's not sure what to do about Solomon. He chooses to do nothing. Solomon is left dangling by the neck from the tree as Chapin calls to Sam in the

Speaker: chapin
Dialogue: Sam! Get the mule. You must ride to Master Ford. Tell him to come here at once without a single moment's delay. Tell him they are trying to murder Platt. Hurry, boy. Bring him back if you must kill the mule to do so!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yes, suh! Sam mounts up and rides off, the mule demonstrating much speed.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Platt... My poor Platt. Ford produces a blade and cuts Solomon loose. Solomon attempts to carry himself, but he cannot. He falls to the ground and passes out.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: I believe Tibeats is skulkin' about the premises somewhere. He wants you dead, and he will attempt to have you so. It's no longer safe for you here. And I don't believe you will remain passive if Tibeats attacks. I have transferred my debt to Edwin Epps. He will take charge of you.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Master Ford, you must know; I am not a slave.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: I cannot hear that.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Before I came to you I was a freeman.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: I am trying to save your life! And...I have a debt to be mindful of. That, now, is to Edwin Epps. He is a hard man. Prides himself on being a "nigger breaker." But truthfully I could find no others who would have you. You've made a reputation of yourself. Whatever your circumstances, you are an exceptional nigger, Platt. I fear no good will come of it.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: "And that servant which knew his Lord's will...WHICH KNEW HIS LORD'S WILL and prepared not himself...PREPARED NOT HIMSELF, neither did according to his will, shall be beaten with many stripes..." D'ye hear that? "Stripes." That nigger that don't take care, that don't obey his lord - that's his master - d'ye see? - that 'ere nigger shall be beaten with many stripes. Now, "many" signifies a great many. Forty, a hundred, a hundred and fifty lashes... That's Scripter!

Speaker: edwards
Dialogue: Pick that cotton. Move along now.

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: C'mon. Drive dem niggers. Edward moves among the slaves, applying the whip to them without regard.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Pick dat cotton. Move along now, hear?

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: Two hundred forty pounds for Bob.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: What yah got for James?

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: Two hundred ninety five pounds.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Tha's real good, boy. Tha's real good.

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: One hundred eighty two pounds for Platt. Epps does not look happy. Treach says again:

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: How much can even an average nigger pick a day?

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: Two hundred pounds.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: This nigger ain't even average. Epps pulls Solomon aside.

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: Five hundred twelve pounds for Patsey.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Five hundred twelve. Yah men folk got no shame lettin' Patsey out pick yah? The day ain't yet come she swung lower than five hundred pounds. Queen of the fields, she is.

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: Two hundred six pou--

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: I ain't done, Treach. Ain't I owed a minute to luxuriate on the work Patsey done?

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Damned Queen. Born and bred to the field. A nigger among niggers, and God give 'er to me. A lesson in the rewards of righteous livin'. All be observant ta that. All!

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: One hundred thirty eight pounds for Phebe.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Hit one forty five yesterday. Pull her out.

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: Two hundred six pounds for Wiley.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: How much he pick yesterday?

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: Two hundred twenty nine pounds. Wiley is pulled from the line, huddled with Solomon.

Speaker: uncle abram
Dialogue: Hold my words: General Jackson will forever be immortalized. His bravery will be handed down to the last posterity. If ever there be a stain upon "raw militia," he done wiped away on the eight of January. I say da result a that day's battle is of 'mo importance to our grand nation than any occurrence 'fo or since. Great man. Great man in deed. We all need pray to Heavenly Father da General reign over us always.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Get up! Get up, we dance tonight! We will not waste the evenin' with yer laziness. Get up.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Where's yah merriment? Move yer feet. As the slaves twirl about Epps keeps an attentive eye on Patsey. It should be quite clear that his primary motivation for holding dances is so that he may view Patsey twirl about the floor. This fact is not lost on Mistress Epps. A few moments of Epps's lust on display is all that the Mistress can bear. Jealousy mounting, she snatches up a CARAFE. With all her might she throws it at Patsey. It hits Patsey square in the face. TOO THICK TO SHATTER, IT LEAVES HER BLOODY AND WRITHING ON THE FLOOR. The dancing, the music stop. The slaves, however, react as though it is not the first time they've seen as much from the Mistress. Mistress Epps, screaming like a hellion:

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: Sell her!

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: C'mon, now. Wha's this?

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: You will sell the negress!

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: You're talkin' foolish. Sell little Pats? She pick with more vigor than any other nigger! Choose another ta go.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: No other. Sell her!

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: I will not!

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: You will remove that black bitch from this property, 'er I'll take myself back to Cheneyville.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Back to that hog's trough where I found you? Oh, the idleness of that yarn washes over me. Do not set yourself up against Patsey, my dear. That's a wager on which you will not profit. Calm yerself. And settle for my affection, 'cause my affection you got. Or, go. 'Cause I will rid myself of yah well before I do away with her! Mistress Epps stands irate, lost in fury and unable to even think of what to do. Eventually, optionless, she storms away. For a few beats there is only the sound of Patsey sobbing.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: Platt...

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Yes, Mistress.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: Can you find your way to Bartholomew's?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I can, ma'am. Handing Solomon a sheet of paper.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: This is a list of goods and sundries. You will take it to be filled and return immediately. Tell Bartholomew to add it to our debt.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I will, Mistress. Solomon looks at the list. In a careless moment, Solomon reads quietly from it. He catches himself, but not before the Mistress notes his action. With high

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: Where yah from, Platt?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I have told you.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: Tell me again.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Washington.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: Who were yah Master?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Master name of Freeman.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: Was he a learned man?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I suppose so.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: He learn yah ta read?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: A word here or there, but I have no understanding of the written text.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: Don't trouble yer self with it. Same as the rest, Master bought yah to work. Tha's all. And any more'll earn yah a hun'red lashes. Having delivered her cool advice, Mistress heads back into the house.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: Any trouble?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: No, ma'am. No trouble.

Speaker: master shaw
Dialogue: Platt Epps, good Sunday morning.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Good morning, Master Shaw. I've been sent by Master to retrieve Patsey. May I approach?

Speaker: master shaw
Dialogue: You may. Solomon makes his way over to the piazza.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Excuse me, Mistress Shaw.

Speaker: mistress shaw
Dialogue: Nigger Platt.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: My apologies. Patsey, Master wishes you to return.

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: Sabbath day. I's free ta roam.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Understood. But the Master sent me running to fetch you, and said no time should be wasted.

Speaker: mistress shaw
Dialogue: Drink tea?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Thank you, Mistress, but I don't dare.

Speaker: mistress shaw
Dialogue: Would you knowed Massa Epps's consternation ta be any lessened wit your timely return? Sit. Sit and drink the tea that offered.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: ...I'd rather not say...

Speaker: mistress shaw
Dialogue: L'il gossip on the Sabbath be fine. All things in moderation. Solomon is not sure what to say. He struggles to be as diplomatic as possible.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: As you are aware, Master Epps can be a man of a hard countenance. There are times when it is impossible to account for his logic. You know he has ill feelings toward your husband.

Speaker: mistress shaw
Dialogue: He do.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Master Epps has somehow come to believe, as incorrectly as it may be, that Master Shaw is... That he is something of a lothario and an unprincipled man. A misguided belief born out of their mutual competition as planters, no doubt.

Speaker: mistress shaw
Dialogue: No doubt...if not born outta truth itself. The Mistress waves to Shaw. Shaw, unsuspecting of the conversation, waves back.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I'm certain Patsey's well being is Master Epps's only concern.

Speaker: mistress shaw
Dialogue: Nothin' Epps desire come outta concern.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I meant no disrespect.

Speaker: mistress shaw
Dialogue: He ain't heard you.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I meant no disrespect to you, Mistress.

Speaker: mistress shaw
Dialogue: Ha! You worry for me? Got no cause to worry for my sensibilities. I ain't felt the end of a lash in 'mo years than I cain recall. Ain't worked a field, neither. Where one time I served, now I got others servin' me. The cost to my current existence be Massa Shaw broadcasting his affections, 'n me enjoyin' his pantomime of fidelity. If that what keep me from the cotton pickin' niggers, that what it be. A small and reasonable price to be paid 'fo sure. Looking toward Patsey, speaking with great empathy:

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Pats...! Patsey!

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Do not look in his direction. Continue on. Epps does not care to be ignored. He lifts himself and moves toward the pair in a rage.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Patsey...! Solomon moves between Epps and Patsey, cutting Epps off as Patsey continues on. Playing up his "ignorance" of

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Found her, Master, and brought her back just as instructed.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: What'd you jus now tell her? What'd you say to Pats?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: No words were spoken. None of consequence.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Lie! Damned liar! Saw you talkin' with 'er. Tell me!

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I cannot speak of what did not occur. Epps grabs Solomon.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: I'll cut your black throat. Solomon pulls away from Epps, RIPPING HIS SHIRT IN THE PROCESS. Epps gives chase. Solomon begins to run around the large pig sty, easily keeping his distance. Epps, however is undeterred. He moves after Solomon as speedily as he can, which isn't very speedily at all. And quickly he tires. Epps is forced to bend over and suck air. Solomon maintains his distance, barely breathing hard. His breath returned to him, Epps starts up the chase again. Solomon runs on out of reach. Shortly, Epps again stops, gets his breath... And now in what should be quite comical, Epps again runs after Solomon. Again, Epps's vigor leaves him before he can even get close to the slave. Dropping down to the dirt, in a show of regret and piety:

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: What? Wha's the fuss?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: A misunderstanding is all. It began when I was sent to retrieve Patsey from where she'd taken sabbatical at Master Shaw's. Upon returning, Master Epps believed Patsey and me to be in conversation when we were not. I tried to explain, but it lead to all this.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: What is it? Ya cain't remain the Sabbath without her under your eye? Ya are a no-account bastard.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Hold a moment...

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: A filthy, godless heathen. My bed is too holy for yah ta share.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Wha's...wha's he been tellin' yah?

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: Of yer misbegotten ways.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: And he would know what of anythin'? I ain't even spoken with him today. Platt, yah lyin' nigger, have I? Have I? Discretion being the better part and all, Solomon remains silent.

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: Get him water. Edward runs to fetch a gourd. He carries it to Henry,

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Go'won. Git up. Unsteadily, Henry lifts himself and goes back to picking cotton. He joins in again with the spiritual, as if the song is all that can keep him going.

Speaker: uncle abram
Dialogue: We dance tonight, massa? Epps remains quietly focused on Patsey. And it's clear from her apprehensive expression just what it is he's come looking for. This time there is no escaping it. As if to acknowledge the badness to come, Phebe lightly cries.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: A moment from the dancing. Come sample what I baked for y'all. The slaves, thankful for the rest as much as the food, file toward the tray reciting a chorus of "Thank you, Mistress." As Patsey moves toward the pastries:

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Seen nothin' but her turn away.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: Are you blind or ignorant? It was hot, hateful scorn. It filled that black face. Yah tell me yah did'n see it, then yah choose not to look, or yah sayin' I lie.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Whatever it was, it passed.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: Is that how yah are with the niggers? Let every ill thought fester inside 'em. Look at 'em.

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: Platt... Platt, you awake?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: I have a request; an act of kindness.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Return it!

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: It yours, Platt.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: For what cause?

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: All I ask: end my life. Take my body to the margin of the swamp-- Solomon looks at Patsey as though she were insane.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: Take me by the throat. Hold me low in the water until I's still 'n without life. Bury me in a lonely place of dyin'.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: No! I will do no such thing. The...the gory detail with which

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: I thought on it long and hard.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: It is melancholia, nothing more. How does such despair even come to you?

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: How can you not know? I got no comfort in this life. If I cain't buy mercy from yah, I'll beg it.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: There are others. Beg them.

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: I'm begging you!

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Why? Why would you consign me to damnation with such an un-Godly request?

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: There is God here! God is merciful, and He forgive merciful acts. Won't be no hell for you. Do it. Do what I ain't got the strength ta do myself. Solomon says nothing. Clearly he's not about to do the deed. With nothing else to do, knowing she is damned with every breath she draws, Patsey crawls back to her spot on the floor and lays herself down.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: It is a plague.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: A plague! It's damn Biblical. Two season God done sent a plague to smite me. I am near ruination. Why, Treach? What I done that God hate me so? Do I not preach His word?

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: I don't care nothin' fer the damn Bayou. I'm sufferin'. Epps looks among his slaves at work, his enmity growing.

Speaker: epps' slave
Dialogue: I hear cutting cane is twice as hard as picking cotton.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: But at least we'll be away from Master Epps.

Speaker: uncle abram
Dialogue: Boy, you two have no sense. Epps returns to his slaves and gives a parting salutation.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Yer Judge Turner's for the season. More if need be, until my crop return. Yah'll bring no disrespect to me, and yah'll bring no biblical plagues to him. Be decent, ere mark my words, I will deliver an ungodly whippin'.

Speaker: overseer
Dialogue: Draw the cane from the rick, cut the top and flags from the stalk, understand? Leave only that part which is sound and healthy. Cast off the rest...

Speaker: zachary
Dialogue: Off the porch. Get off. Like a dog shooed away, Solomon steps down. Eventually Judge Turner exits the house and crosses to Solomon.

Speaker: judge turner
Dialogue: Platt is it? Have you cultivated cane previously?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: No, sir, I have not.

Speaker: judge turner
Dialogue: You take to it quite naturally. Are you educated?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Niggers are hired to work, not to read and write. Turner gives that a bit of consideration as he gives Solomon a wary looking over.

Speaker: judge turner
Dialogue: You play the fiddle?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: judge turner
Dialogue: Willard Yarney, a planter up the bayou, celebrates his anniversary in a three week's time. I will hold out your name to him. What you earn is yours to keep.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Sir.

Speaker: judge turner
Dialogue: Mind yourself, Platt.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: C'mere. C'mon, boy.

Speaker: uncle abram
Dialogue: Runaways I would expect. The Bayou full with 'em. They nothin' 'mo dangerous than a nigger in flight.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: They acted out of desperation.

Speaker: uncle abram
Dialogue: Act outta lunacy. Heads fulla stories 'bout life up north. Yah ever been north, Platt?

Speaker: uncle abram
Dialogue: And never should yah be. I hope that yah never bear witness the sorry condition of the northern black. Got neither no purpose, nor direction. They jus...they jus fall about the streets in search of sustenance of both body and spirit.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: You know this to be so?

Speaker: uncle abram
Dialogue: Two of my massas tolt me.

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: I am hungry. Give me food.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: I'm hungry. Solomon gives Celeste some of his food. Celeste, famished, devours it.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: What is your name?

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: My name is Celeste.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: What are your circumstances?

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: I belong ta Massa Carey, and 'ave been two days among da palmettoes. Celeste is sick and cain't work, and would rather die in the swamp

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: There are some whose tracks the hounds will refuse to follow.

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: Give me more food. I'm starvin'.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: This is all my allowance for the

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: Give it to me. Almost as if compelled, Solomon does as ordered. As she eats, Celeste aggrandizes herself:

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: I am hungry. Solomon gives Celeste the handkerchief he's filled. She opens it, and begins to devour the food. As she eats:

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Platt.

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: Was you free?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I was. I am. Solomon exposes his wrist, displays his tattoo as he

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: Free heart means nothin if'n yo body gunna die a slave.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I will not.

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: How? Celeste knows you ain't gunna run. Celeste knows it ain't your nature.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I have a plan. I have a letter.

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: A letter? How'll yah mail da letter? Who yah trust to post it? A nigger that can read and write is a nigger that'll hang. There is a pause. Solomon can't answer this question. It is the glaring hole in his plan. Having finished eating:

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I risk discovery to take more.

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: You will bring Celeste 'mo food. And with that Celeste again moves back into the darkness.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I have my letter.

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: Yah has your freedom then?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: All that remains is to contrive measures by which the letter can safely be deposited in the post office. When Celeste speaks she is quite melancholy.

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: I have resolved to return to my Massa. Solomon gives an unnerved look. This is not good news.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Is it more food you need?

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: I live in fear.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: None will come after you in the swamps.

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: It ain't the patrollers I scared of... At all seasons the howling of wild animals can be heard at night along the border of the swamps. At first their calls were welcomin'. Dey too was free, 'n I thought dey greeted me like a sistah. Lately, dey cries have turned horrifyin'. They mean to kill Celeste.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: The solitude plays tricks. It's your impression, nothing more. If you go back to your master you could face the same.

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: My freedom been nothin' but a daydream. So was Celeste's thoughts of slaves conjoinin' in the bayou.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Better the loneliness. You have been free most of the summer. Return now and your master will make example of you.

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: It is lonely dwellin' waiting for others who won't never come.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Go north. Make your way by night...

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: It'll only be worse if'n Celeste don't go back of her own will.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: You won't be caught. The dogs won't track you. You are...you are unique. Celeste...

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: You got alternatives, Solomon.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: To return is to die!

Speaker: celeste
Dialogue: Celeste got no one to write a letter to. As if to punctuate her resolve, without a word more Celeste departs toward the swamp. Solomon starts on into the swamp after her.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Celeste... Celeste! Solomon continues after Celeste, wading deeper into the dark night and murky waters.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: A joyous day. A joyous day. Dark times is behind us. Clean livin' 'n prayer done lifted the plague. Indicating to the cotton:

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Wiley...?

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: Two hundred sixty pounds.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Bob?

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: Three hundred forty pounds for Bob.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Patsey?

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: Five hundred twenty pounds.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Tha's a girl. Don't never let me down. Platt?

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: One hundred sixty pounds. Before Treach is even done announcing the weight, Epps has pulled Solomon aside to where Uncle Abram already awaits his fate.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Armsby?

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: Sixty four pounds. Epps speaks to Armsby sternly, but nothing of the manner in which he would address the slaves.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: A good days labor would average two hundred pounds.

Speaker: armsby
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: I'm sure in time y'll develope as a picker, but it takes effort, boy. Put some damn effort into it.

Speaker: armsby
Dialogue: Yes, sir. To Treach, regarding Solomon and Abram:

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Take 'em out. Get to whippin'. No force is needed. The slaves understand the situation. They follow Treach out of the Gin house.

Speaker: armsby
Dialogue: It's a tragedy. How does such come to pass? Working a field and picking cotton like a lowly hand. I'm of a damn sight better station. And my desires never lacked for a grandiose component, though I will admit they have at times been short on ingenuity. But only at times. I've worked as an overseer, you know.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I did not, sir.

Speaker: armsby
Dialogue: Not "sir." Just Armsby. Not owed more than any other in the field. I worked plantations from Virginia, down into Alabama. I could manage easy a hundred slaves and have done so.
