Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: How did you arrive at such a place, if I may ask?

Speaker: armsby
Dialogue: Ask. It's just conversation. From a pocket Armsby produces a flask.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Where is your place of birth?

Speaker: armsby
Dialogue: Maryland. Have you traveled there?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: ...I cannot say that I have.

Speaker: armsby
Dialogue: Fine country. More seasonal than the bayou. A deal less humid.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Why did you leave it?

Speaker: armsby
Dialogue: To make my fortune, of course. I gave in to tales of wealth and prosperity that were the lore of the southern states: all that's needed being a patch of land and a few good growing seasons. Cotton,

Speaker: treach
Dialogue: Get him water. Edward runs to fetch water which he carries to Abram and

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I just want to say something about Uncle Abram. He was a good man and he always looked out for us since we were little. God Bless him. God love him. And God keep him. That done, they begin to cover it with dirt. It is all the more of a funeral that Abram will receive.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: The proceeds of my fiddling performances. A few picayunes, but all I have in the world. I promise them to you if you will do me the favor I require. But I beg you not to expose me if you cannot grant the request.

Speaker: armsby
Dialogue: What do you ask?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: First, your word, sir.

Speaker: armsby
Dialogue: On my honor.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: It is a simple enough request. I ask only that you deposit a letter in the Marksville post office. And that you keep the action an inviolable secret forever. The details of the letter are of no consequence. Even at that, there would be an imposition of much pain and suffering were it known I was the author. A patron is what I require, sir.

Speaker: armsby
Dialogue: Where's the letter now?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: ...It is not yet written. I will have it in a day. Two at most, my skill with composition as poor as it is. Armsby considers the request.

Speaker: armsby
Dialogue: I will do it. And will accept whatever payment is offered. Solomon hesitates. In the moment, he's not so sure he can wholly give himself over to trust.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: In two days. ...Thank you. Solomon exits.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Get up. Solomon does. Epps heads back out into the dark. He says nothing, but his directive is clear: Follow me.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Well, boy. I understand I've got a larned nigger that writes

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: All I have to say, master, is all that need be said. There is no truth in it.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: You say.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: How could I write a letter without ink or paper? There is nobody I want to write to 'cause I hain't got no friends living as I know of. That Armsby is a lying drunken fellow. You know this, just as you know that I am constant in truth. Now, master, I can see what that Armsby is after, plain enough. Didn't he want you to hire him for an overseer? A beat.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: I'm damned. I'll be god... Were he not free and white, Platt. Were he not free and white. Epps heads off. Solomon is left to exhale a deep breath.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Take it. You look unsettled.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: I'm well.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: No shame in taking respite from the heat; drink, shade. It's ungodly for travelers. Hearty, or otherwise.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: Your humor is inadvertent. Sensing perhaps Bass's laughter might be at his expense, Epps presses.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Then share what's funny. Or what ills you.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: I'm here to complete the work at hand. As requested, and as paid.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Something rubs you wrongly. Before I take further offense, I offer you the opportunity to speak on it.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: You ask plainly, I will tell you plainly. What I find amusing: You worry about my well being in the heat but, quite frankly, the condition of your laborers--

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: "The condition of my..." What in the hell are you--

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: It is horrid. It's all wrong. All wrong, sir.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: They ain't hired help. They're my slaves.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: You say that with pride.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: I say it as fact.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: If the conversation concerns what is factual and what is not; there's no justice nor righteousness in slavery. I wouldn't own a slave if I was rich as Croesus, which I am not, as is perfectly well understood. More particularly among my creditors. There's another humbug: the credit system. Humbug, sir. No credit, no debt. Credit leads a man into temptation. Cash down is the only thing that will deliver him from

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: What right? I bought 'em. I paid for 'em.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: Of course you did. The law says you have the right to hold a nigger, but begging the law's pardon...it lies. Is everything right because the law allows it? Suppose they'd pass a law taking away your liberty and making you a slave?

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Ha!

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: Suppose.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: That ain't a supposable case.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: Because the law states that your liberties are undeniable? Because society deems it so? Laws change. Social systems crumble. Universal truths are constant. It is a fact, it is a plain fact that what is true and right is true and right for all. White and black alike.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Whoa, whoa, whoa. Yah compare me to a nigger, Bass? Yah might as well ask what the difference is between a white man and a baboon. Now, I seen one of them critters in Orleans that knowed just as much as any nigger I got. Yah'd call them fellers citizens, I s'pose?

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: Look here; you can't laugh me down in that way. These niggers are human beings. If they are allowed to scale no higher than brute animals, you and men like you will have to answer for it. There's an

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Ahhh!

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: A fearful ill, resting on this

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: You betray yourself a foreigner!

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: That will not go unpunished forever. There will be a reckoning yet.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: You like to hear yourself talk, Bass, better than any man I know of. Yah'd argue that black was white, or white black if anybody would contradict you. A fine supposition if yah lived among Yankees in New England. But yah don't.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Patsey... Patsey! A drunk Epps asks of the slaves:

Speaker: phebe
Dialogue: We know nothin' of her, Massa.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: The hell you don't! You know where she is! She run off, ain't she? She's escaped, and you miserable black dogs stand like

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Run off. Run off, did you?

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: You miserable wench! Where you been?

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: I been nowhere.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Lies to your misdeeds!

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: The Sabbath day, Massa. I took me a walk to commune wit da Lord.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Bring the Lord into yer deceptions? Yah Godless... Shaw's. Comin' from Shaw's plantation weren't yah?

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Yah took yerself ta pleasure Shaw. Yah gave baser passion to that unblushin' libertine! Solomon tries to intervene:

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Now yah speak? Now that yah want to add to 'er lies yah find yer tongue. Epps goes to strike Solomon, but Patsey pulls his arm back.

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: Do not strike him. I went to Massa Shaw's plantation!

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Yah admit it.

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: Freely. And you know why. Patsey takes soap from the pocket of her dress.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: You lie...

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: The Lord knows that's all.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: You lie!

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: And you blind wit yer own covetousness. I don't lie, Massa. If you kill me, I'll stick ta that.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: I'll learn you to go to Shaw's. Treach, go get some line.

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: Do it! Strike the life from her. Epps again hoists the whip. It trembles in his hand ahead of the act... But he does not have it in him to deliver such a beating. Turning to Solomon, thrusting the whip at him:

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Beat her. Solomon doesn't move. Epps shoves the whip into his hand.

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: I'd rather it you, Platt.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Strike her, or yah'll get the same!

Speaker: mistress epps
Dialogue: He pantomimes. There ain't barely a welt on her. That's what your niggers make of yah; a fool fer the takin'. Epps's grief is replaced by fury. EPPS GRABS THE PISTOL FROM TREACH'S HOLSTER and draws down on the slaves.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Yah will strike her. Yah will strike her until her flesh is rent and meat and blood flow equal, or I will kill every nigger in my sight! Solomon can't strike a blow, even if it means his life. But from the ground, from Patsey:

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: Do it, Platt. Don't stop until I am dead. What else can he do? Solomon begins to whip, to truly whip Patsey. Her back welts, then tears... Patsey screams in agony. Solomon strikes again and again... After a full thirty lashes Solomon looks to Epps, who is not satisfied.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Until I say no more! I ain't said nothing! Solomon strikes another ten to fifteen times. By now, as promised, Patsey's back has been reduced to LITTLE MORE

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Thou devil! Sooner or later, somewhere in the course of eternal justice thou shalt answer for this sin! Though Epps fronts rage, there should be underlying anguish for what he has done to his beloved Pats.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: No sin! There is no sin! A man does how he pleases with his property. At the moment, Platt, I am of great pleasure. You be goddamn careful I don't come to wantin' to lightenin' my mood no further. By contrast to this horror, the field of cotton smiles in the warm sunlight. The birds chirp merrily amidst the foliage of the tress. Peace and happiness seems to reign everywhere. Everywhere else. Epps leaves Patsey to herself. He says not a word to the Mistress as he passes. The Mistress herself heads back into the house. Solomon unties Patsey, lifts her and takes her to the cabin.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Master Bass, I want to ask you what part of the country you came from?

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: No part of this land. I was born in Canada. Now guess where that is.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Oh, I know where Canada is. I have been there myself.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: Have you?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Montreal and Kingston and Queenston and a great many places. And I have been in York state, too. Buffalo and Rochester and Albany, and can tell you the names of the villages on the Erie canal and the Champlain canal. Bass gives Solomon a long and curious stare.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: Well traveled for a slave. How came you here?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Master Bass, if justice had been done I never would have been here.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: How's this? Tell me all about it.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I am afraid to tell you, though I don't believe you would tell Master Epps if I should.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: Every word you speak is a profound secret.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: How many years all told?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Just nearly...just passed eleven.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: Your story is...it is amazing, and in no good way.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Do you believe, sir, in justice as you have said?

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: That slavery is an evil that should befall none?

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: I believe so.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: If you truly do, I would ask...I would beg that you write my friends in the north, acquainting them with my situation and beseeching them to forward free papers, or take such steps as they might consider proper to secure my release. Bass looks at Solomon, holding his gaze for more than a prolonged beat.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: I have always forgone relationships and family. I did once have a sweetheart who I loved deeply. Bass points to a measuring tool, which Solomon immediately hands over.

Speaker: slow dissolve
Dialogue: To a now virtually complete, half-painted white gazebo. Slaves continue to work on it. As they do so, Bass peels away from the structure to have an overview. He beckons Solomon toward him, out of earshot from the slaves who are continuing to work on the gazebo. As Solomon approaches, Bass shouts-

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: And bring those markers! Solomon gathers a clutch of markers in his hands and approaches Bass.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: You are certain? Bass takes a marker from Solomon and slides it into the earth.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: I have inquired thoroughly. More than is safe for either of us. Bass takes another and pokes it into the ground, improvising a pathway towards the gazebo.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Five months. On top of these years. No cause remains.

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: If there is any chance...

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Mr. Bass...

Speaker: bass
Dialogue: I will continue to write your

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Go home knowing you have tried. The weight of defeat should hang very heavily with both men. Nothing more to do, nothing more to say BASS TAKES

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Platt...? Where is the boy called Platt?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: ...Sir... The Sheriff crosses to him.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Your name is Platt, is it?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Yes, sir. Pointing off to the distance.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Do you know that man?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Mr. Parker...?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Say again?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Mr. Parker? As he does, Epps makes his way over.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: That man received a letter compiling many accusations. You look me in the eye and on your life answer me truthfully: have you any other name than Platt?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Solomon Northup is my name.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Sheriff...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Have you a family?

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: What's all this?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: It's official business.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: My nigger, my business.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Your business waits.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I have a wife and two children.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: What were your children's names?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Margaret and Alonzo.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: And your wife's name before her marriage?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Anne Hampton. I am who I say. Solomon pushes past the sheriff. As Solomon moves toward Parker, his pace quickens with each step until his

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: Nah... You will unhand 'em. Platt is my nigger!

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: He is Solomon Northup.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: You say...

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: He belongs to no man.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: You say! You come here, unfamiliar to me, and make claims.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Not claims. I have no doubts. This is Solomon Northup, a resident of Saratoga Springs, NY.

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: To hell with that! My nigger, and I'll fight you for 'em!

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: As is your right. As it will be my pleasure to bankrupt you in the courts. Your decision. By this time, the slaves in the plantation have overcome their fear of penalty, and left their work and gathered in the yard as witnesses. They stand behind the cabin, out of sight of Epps. Mistress Epps also bears witness, standing on the veranda next to her house slave. Her face is of a strange mixed emotion. Epps looks to Solomon. Solomon icily, stoically holds his ground. He makes it quite clear in his countenance that nobody owns him. Sheriff, hand on his gun, is there to back Solomon up. Epps, with no other recourse than to

Speaker: epps
Dialogue: You think this is the last you'll see of me, boy? It ain't.

Speaker: patsey
Dialogue: Platt... Disregarding Parker, Solomon crosses over to Patsey. Under the circumstances, neither really knows how to engage. Finally, suddenly, Patsey throws her arms around Solomon and they embrace. Epps, now mounted on his horse, witness the encounter. Kicking the stirrups hard into the sides of the horse, he rides off furiously. Calling from the carriage, mindful of Epps:

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Solomon...if we know what's wise, we should depart. A moment longer Solomon and Patsey hold each other. They separate, Solomon heading back to the carriage. He and Parker alight. The Sheriff chides the horses and they

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Are you ready? Solomon swallows and nods.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I apologize for my appearance. I have had a difficult time of things these past many years. Solomon looks among his family; trying to recall them as much as they look to see familiarity within him. To his

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: He is my husband.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Husband?

Speaker: margaret's husband
Dialogue: It is very good to meet you, sir.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: We have much acquainting to do. Margaret rises, she presents her bundle to her father.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: And this is your grandson. Solomon Northup Staunton.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: ...Solomon... The fact his grandson carries his name, is overwhelming. Solomon breaks down. Emotionally, physically... But ANNE IS THERE TO CATCH HIM. As she holds him, Solomon says to Anne with all his heart:

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: There is nothing to forgive. The pair, joined now by the whole family, hold on to each other for life...and one would think for all the rest of their lives.
